title: Reforming Support for Special Educational Needs in England
summary: The UK government has announced that it will not withdraw effective support from children with special educational needs and disabilities (SEND) as part of planned school reforms in England. Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson emphasized increased funding for SEND support, addressing concerns from parents who fear potential limitations. Under the proposals, children will undergo needs assessments upon transitioning to secondary school, with leaks indicating reassessments for those with Education, Health and Care Plans (EHCPs) starting in 2029. Additionally, the government plans to introduce Individual Support Plans (ISPs) for all children with identified SEND, granting legal rights and quicker access to assistance. Phillipson assured that EHCPs will remain important, but ISPs will streamline support, reducing parental struggles. The full details will be outlined in a White Paper released on Monday, responding to a SEND system in crisis due to rising costs. The minister described this as a decade-long transition to improve a flawed system.

background_read: In England, the SEND system supports children with special educational needs and disabilities, but it faces challenges like high costs and inefficiencies. Currently, EHCPs are legal documents that ensure support, but parents often struggle to obtain them. The government is proposing reforms to address these issues, including introducing Individual Support Plans (ISPs) to extend legal rights and streamline assistance. These changes come amid concerns from parents about potential support reductions. The reforms aim to create a more effective and sustainable system over a ten-year period, as detailed in an upcoming White Paper.
Article_Structure: The article outlines the UK government's SEND reform proposals, with main points including no withdrawal of effective support, increased funding, and new Individual Support Plans. Its purpose is to reassure parents and address systemic crises by detailing planned changes. Evidence evaluation relies on minister statements and leaked documents, though full details are pending the White Paper. Author credibility is high as BBC News is a reputable source, but potential bias from government sources exists. Methodology involves reporting on official announcements and leaks, with critical assessment noting the need for more concrete evidence and parent perspectives.
